focus_skills: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 13 to both sides: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></math>. Divide by 5: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations on both sides of the equation.

questions.question: The line with equation <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math> passes through the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute the coordinates into the equation: <math><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>. This simplifies to <math><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>. Solving gives <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: A point lies on a line if its coordinates satisfy the line's equation. Substitute and solve for the unknown.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><mn>6</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Distribute: <math><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Combine like terms: <math><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>42</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the distributive property carefully, paying attention to signs. Then combine like terms systematically.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread

questions.question_chart_description: A bar chart showing the average weekly study hours for four grade levels. The y-axis ranges from 0 to 10. The heights of the bars are: Freshmen (6 hours), Sophomores (8 hours), Juniors (4 hours), and Seniors (10 hours).
questions.question: The bar chart above shows the average number of hours students in four different grade levels study per week. Based on the chart, which grade level has the highest average weekly study hours?
questions.explanation: To determine which grade level has the highest average, identify the tallest bar in the chart. The bar for 'Seniors' reaches the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>10</mn></math>-hour mark on the vertical axis, which is higher than the bars for Freshmen (<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>6</mn></math>), Sophomores (<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>8</mn></math>), and Juniors (<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn></math>).
questions.score_improvement_tip: For bar charts, simply compare the height of the bars. The tallest bar represents the category with the greatest value.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the system. From the second equation: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi></math>. Substitute into the first: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. So <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving a system of equations, look for the most efficient method (substitution, elimination) based on how the equations are arranged. Sometimes solving for the combination of variables (like x+y) directly is faster than finding each variable individually.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math><mi>c</mi></math> is a constant. If the graph of <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> in the xy-plane intersects the x-axis at exactly one point, what is the value of <math><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: A parabola intersects the x-axis at exactly one point when its vertex lies on the x-axis, meaning the quadratic equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has a double root (discriminant = 0). The discriminant is <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>−6</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>c</mi></math>. Set equal to 0: <math><mn>36</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mn>4</mn><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math> → <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The number of x-intercepts of a quadratic function is determined by its discriminant (b² - 4ac). One intercept means discriminant = 0.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='250' viewBox='0 0 350 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='250' fill='white'/><text x='175' y='20' text-anchor='middle' font-size='12' font-family='Arial' fill='gray'>Note: Figure not drawn to scale.</text><polygon points='100,200 100,50 250,200' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M100,190 L110,190 L110,200' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='100' y='40' text-anchor='middle' font-size='14' font-family='Arial' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='90' y='210' text-anchor='end' font-size='14' font-family='Arial' font-weight='bold'>C</text><text x='260' y='210' text-anchor='start' font-size='14' font-family='Arial' font-weight='bold'>B</text><text x='85' y='125' text-anchor='end' font-size='14' font-family='Arial'>15</text><text x='175' y='220' text-anchor='middle' font-size='14' font-family='Arial' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='185' y='115' text-anchor='start' font-size='14' font-family='Arial'>17</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right-angled triangle ABC with the right angle at vertex C. The vertical leg AC has length 15. The horizontal leg BC has length x. The hypotenuse AB has length 17.
questions.question: In the right triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi></math> is a right angle. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
Since triangle ABC is a right triangle with the right angle at C, the Pythagorean theorem applies: AC2+BC2=AB2.

1. Substitute the known values: 152+x2=172.
2. Simplify the squares: 225+x2=289.
3. Solve for x2: x2=289-225=64.
4. Take the square root: x=64=8.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the hypotenuse first—it's always opposite the right angle. Then use <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question: A store increased the price of an item by 25%. After a few weeks, the store decreased the new price by <math><mi>k</mi></math>% so that the final price was 10% greater than the original price. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Let the original price be <math><mi>P</mi></math>. After a 25% increase, the price becomes <math><mn>1.25</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. A decrease of <math><mi>k</mi></math>% means multiplying by <math><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>. The final price is <math><mn>1.25</mn><mi>P</mi><mo>×</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>. This is equal to <math><mn>1.10</mn><mi>P</mi></math> (10% greater than original). Cancel <math><mi>P</mi></math>: <math><mn>1.25</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.10</mn></math>. Solve: <math><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1.10</mn><mn>1.25</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.88</mn></math>. So <math><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.12</mn></math>, and <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For successive percent changes, use multiplication factors (e.g., a p% increase multiplies by (1 + p/100)). Set up an equation and solve for the unknown percentage.

questions.question: What is the positive solution to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the quadratic: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. The positive solution is <math><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To solve a quadratic equation, first try factoring. Look for two numbers that multiply to the constant term (-36) and add to the linear coefficient (5).

questions.question: Which of the following numbers is a solution to the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the inequality: <math><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. Subtract 3 from both sides: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Subtract 7x: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Divide by -9 (remember to reverse the inequality sign): <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math>. So the solution set is all numbers greater than or equal to approximately -0.777. Check the options: -2 and -1 are less than -0.777, so they are NOT solutions. 0 and 1 are both ≥ -0.777. Among these, 0 is listed as option C.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving inequalities, remember to reverse the inequality sign if you multiply or divide by a negative number. Always check your solution by testing a value from the solution set.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='450' height='250' viewBox='0 0 450 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='450' height='250' fill='white'/><g transform='translate(20, 20)'><text x='100' y='20' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>Data Set A</text><line x1='20' y1='150' x2='180' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><rect x='30' y='140' width='20' height='10' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='50' y='120' width='20' height='30' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='70' y='50' width='20' height='100' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='90' y='50' width='20' height='100' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='110' y='50' width='20' height='100' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='130' y='120' width='20' height='30' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='150' y='140' width='20' height='10' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><text x='100' y='170' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>Value</text></g><g transform='translate(240, 20)'><text x='100' y='20' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>Data Set B</text><line x1='20' y1='150' x2='180' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><rect x='30' y='50' width='20' height='100' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='50' y='100' width='20' height='50' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='70' y='130' width='20' height='20' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='90' y='130' width='20' height='20' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='110' y='130' width='20' height='20' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='130' y='100' width='20' height='50' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><rect x='150' y='50' width='20' height='100' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><text x='100' y='170' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>Value</text></g></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two histograms labeled Data Set A and Data Set B. Data Set A shows a bell-shaped distribution with most data clustered tightly in the center (tall bars in the middle, short bars on the ends). Data Set B shows a U-shaped distribution with most data at the extremes (tall bars on the ends, short bars in the middle). Both sets span the same range and appear to have the same mean.
questions.question: Two data sets, A and B, are summarized by the histograms shown. Both sets have the same range and the same mean. Which of the following statements correctly compares the standard deviations of the two data sets?

options.A: The standard deviation of Data Set A is less than the standard deviation of Data Set B.
options.B: The standard deviation of Data Set A is greater than the standard deviation of Data Set B.
options.C: The standard deviation of Data Set A is equal to the standard deviation of Data Set B.
options.D: There is not enough information to compare the standard deviations.

questions.explanation:
Standard deviation measures the average distance of data points from the mean.

1. Analyze Data Set A: The histogram shows a large cluster of data in the center, very close to the mean. Since most points are near the mean, the average distance is small.

2. Analyze Data Set B: The histogram shows the data clustered at the far left and right ends, far away from the mean (which is in the center). Since most points are far from the mean, the average distance is large.

Therefore, Data Set B has a larger standard deviation than Data Set A.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Think of standard deviation as 'spread from the center.' If data is clustered in the middle, SD is low. If data is pushed to the edges (extremes), SD is high.

questions.question:
In the system of equations below, a and b are constants.
2x+ay=16
bx−4y=20
If the system has no solution, what is the value of ab?
questions.explanation: A system of linear equations has no solution when the lines are parallel (same slope, different y-intercepts). Write both equations in slope-intercept form (<math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>). First equation: <math><mi>a</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>16</mn><mi>a</mi></mfrac></math>. Slope <math><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mfrac></math>. Second equation: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>20</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Slope <math><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. For parallel lines: <math><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. So <math><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. Cross-multiply: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></math>. To find <math><mi>a</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, solve for the ratio: <math><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: A system has no solution when the lines are parallel (equal slopes) but have different y-intercepts. Convert equations to slope-intercept form to compare slopes and intercepts.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='250' viewBox='0 0 350 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='250' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><polygon points='100,180 220,180 260,130 140,130' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='100,180 100,80 140,30 140,130' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><rect x='100' y='80' width='120' height='100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='220,180 220,80 260,30 260,130' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='140' y1='30' x2='260' y2='30' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='100' y1='180' x2='260' y2='30' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' stroke-dasharray='6,3'/><text x='160' y='195' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>12</text><text x='250' y='170' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>9</text><text x='180' y='100' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>d = 25</text><text x='85' y='130' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>h</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A rectangular prism with length 12 and width 9. The space diagonal connecting opposite corners is labeled d = 25. The height is labeled h.
questions.question: A rectangular prism has a length of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn></math> units and a width of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>9</mn></math> units. The length of the space diagonal of the prism is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>25</mn></math> units. What is the total surface area, in square units, of the prism?
questions.explanation:
To find the surface area, we first need to determine the height h of the prism using the space diagonal formula.

1. Find the height (h):
The formula for the space diagonal d is d2=l2+w2+h2.
Substitute the given values:
252=122+92+h2
625=144+81+h2
625=225+h2
h2=400
h=20

2. Calculate Total Surface Area (SA):
The formula for surface area is SA=2(lw+lh+wh).
SA=2((12)(9)+(12)(20)+(9)(20))
SA=2(108+240+180)
SA=2(528)
SA=1056
questions.score_improvement_tip: For rectangular prisms: Space Diagonal <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><msup><mi>l</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>w</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>h</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt></math> and Surface Area <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>S</mi><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>w</mi><mi>h</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></math>.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrowhead' questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot showing Car Age vs. Value. The x-axis represents Age in years (0 to 12) and the y-axis represents Value in thousands of dollars (0 to 20). A line of best fit trends downwards. A specific data point at x=4 corresponds to y=14 ($14,000). The line of best fit passes below this point.
questions.question: The scatterplot above shows the age, in years, and the estimated value, in thousands of dollars, for several used cars. The dashed line represents the line of best fit for the data, which is defined by the equation <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1.3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>17.2</mn></math>, where <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> is the age in years and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math> is the predicted value in thousands of dollars. For the car that is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn></math> years old, what is the residual (the difference between the actual value and the predicted value)?
questions.explanation:
To find the residual, we must subtract the predicted value (calculated using the equation of the line of best fit) from the actual value (found on the scatterplot).

1. Find the Actual Value:
Locate x=4 on the horizontal axis. Identify the data point (black dot) directly above this age. The point aligns with 14 on the vertical axis, representing $14,000.

2. Find the Predicted Value:
Substitute x=4 into the given equation:
y=-1.3(4)+17.2
y=-5.2+17.2
y=12
The predicted value is $12,000.

3. Calculate the Residual:
Residual=Actual-Predicted
Residual=14,000-12,000=2,000.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In 'Hard' difficulty questions, do not rely solely on the visual line for the predicted value if an equation is provided. Visual lines are approximations; the equation provides the exact predicted value required for the calculation.

questions.question: The function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by a linear equation. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></math> for some constant <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>k</mi></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation:
Because f is a linear function, its slope (rate of change) is constant. We can find the slope m using the two given values, even without knowing k.

1. Find the slope (m):
The change in input (x) is (k+4)-k=4.
The change in output (f(x)) is -14-(-2)=-12.
m=-124=-3.

2. Determine the target value:
We need to find f(k-2). The input k-2 represents a change in x of -2 from the original point k.

3. Calculate the new output:
Using the linear property ∆y=m(∆x):
∆y=-3(-2)=6.
Add this change to the value at f(k):
f(k-2)=-2+6=4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When function inputs involve variables (like k and k+4), focus on the 'change in x' rather than solving for the variable itself. The slope formula applies to the difference between inputs regardless of whether they are numbers or expressions.

questions.question: The equation <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></math> is true for all values of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>, where <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>c</mi></math> are constants. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mi>b</mi></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To find c, we must first find the values of a and b by expanding the left side of the equation and matching coefficients.

1. Expand the left side:
(ax+2)(bx-4)=abx2-4ax+2bx-8
Group the x-terms:
abx2+(2b-4a)x-8

2. Match coefficients:
Compare this to 24x2+cx-8.
For the x2 term: ab=24.
For the x term: c=2b-4a.

3. Solve for a and b:
We have a system of equations:
1) ab=24
2) a+b=11
The factors of 24 that add up to 11 are 8 and 3. Since the problem states a>b, we must assign:
a=8 and b=3.

4. Solve for c:
Substitute these values into the expression for c:
c=2(3)-4(8)
c=6-32
c=-26
questions.score_improvement_tip: When matching coefficients for polynomial identities, expand the factored form completely and group terms by degree (e.g., all x-terms together). This creates a system of equations allowing you to solve for unknown constants.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: Machine A can complete a specific production task in <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi></math> minutes. Machine B requires <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math> more time than Machine A to complete the same task. If both machines working together can complete the task in <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn></math> minutes, how many minutes does it take Machine B to complete the task alone?
questions.explanation:
We can model the work rate of each machine as 1time.

1. Define variables:
Let the time it takes Machine A be m minutes.
Since Machine B takes 50% longer, its time is 1.5m minutes.

2. Set up the rate equation:
Rate of A + Rate of B = Combined Rate
1m+11.5m=112

3. Solve for m:
To add the fractions on the left, find a common denominator (1.5m):
1.51.5m+11.5m=112
2.51.5m=112
Cross-multiply:
1.5m=2.5(12)
1.5m=30
m=20

4. Find Machine B's time:
The question asks for Machine B's time, which is 1.5m.
1.5(20)=30 minutes.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In 'work together' problems involving unknown times, use the formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>a</mi></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>b</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>t</mi></mfrac></math>. Be careful to note whether the question asks for the base variable or a modified value (like '50% longer').

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='0' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><line x1='150' y1='280' x2='150' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' marker-end='url(#arrow)'/><line x1='20' y1='150' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' marker-end='url(#arrow)'/><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='100' fill='none' stroke='#666' stroke-width='1.5' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><line x1='150' y1='150' x2='188' y2='58' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='150' y1='150' x2='58' y2='112' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='188' cy='58' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='58' cy='112' r='4' fill='black'/><text x='200' y='55' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>A(5, 12)</text><text x='35' y='105' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='155' y='165' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>O(0,0)</text><path d='M 180 78 A 80 80 0 0 0 78 120' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='110' y='80' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' fill='blue'>s = 13π/2</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: The xy-coordinate plane showing a circle centered at the origin O(0,0). Point A is located at (5, 12) on the circle. Point B is another point on the circle. Radii OA and OB are drawn. The minor arc AB connecting these points is highlighted and labeled with length 13pi/2.
questions.question: In the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane, a circle with center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> passes through point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math> lies on the circle such that the length of minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>⌢</mo></mover></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mrow><mn>13</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. What is the measure, in degrees, of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To find the angle measure, we first determine the radius of the circle and then use the arc length formula.

1. Find the radius (r):
Since the circle is centered at (0,0) and passes through (5,12), the radius is the distance from the origin to A.
r=52+122=25+144=169=13.

2. Use the Arc Length Formula:
The length of an arc s is given by s=θ360×2πr, where θ is the central angle in degrees.
Substitute the known values:
13π2=θ360×2π(13)

3. Solve for θ:
13π2=θ360×26π
Divide both sides by 13π:
12=θ360×2
12=2θ360
360=4θ
θ=90.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a circle question provides coordinates for a point on the circumference and the center is at the origin, use the Pythagorean triples (like 5-12-13) to quickly find the radius. Then, set up a proportion: (Arc Length / Circumference) = (Angle / 360).

questions.question: A box contains only red and blue marbles. The ratio of the number of red marbles to the number of blue marbles is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. When <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn></math> blue marbles are added to the box, the probability of randomly selecting a red marble becomes <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. How many red marbles are in the box?
questions.explanation:
We can express the number of marbles using a multiplier x based on the initial ratio.

1. Set up the initial expressions:
Ratio of Red:Blue = 3:5.
Let Red marbles = 3x.
Let Blue marbles = 5x.
Total initial marbles = 8x.

2. Account for the change:
12 blue marbles are added.
New Blue count = 5x+12.
The number of Red marbles stays the same (3x).
New Total = 8x+12.

3. Set up the probability equation:
The new probability of selecting a red marble is 14.
RedTotal=14
3x8x+12=14

4. Solve for x:
Cross-multiply:
4(3x)=1(8x+12)
12x=8x+12
4x=12
x=3.

5. Calculate the answer:
The question asks for the number of red marbles (3x).
3(3)=9.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a problem gives a ratio (e.g., 3:5), express the quantities as '3x' and '5x'. Remember that probability is always (Part / Whole). If you add items to one group, the 'Whole' increases by that same amount.

questions.question: The function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by the equation <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>c</mi></math> are constants. If the graph of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> in the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane passes through the points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation:
To find f(-1), we must first determine the values of the constants a and c using the given points.

1. Use the point (0, 5):
5=20+a+c
5=2a+c (Equation 1)

2. Use the point (1, 7):
7=21+a+c
Using exponent rules, 21+a=21·2a=2·2a.
7=2·2a+c (Equation 2)

3. Solve the system:
Subtract Equation 1 from Equation 2:
(2·2a+c)-(2a+c)=7-5
2a=2
Therefore, a=1.

Substitute 2a=2 back into Equation 1:
5=2+c
c=3.

The function is f(x)=2x+1+3.

4. Evaluate f(-1):
f(-1)=2-1+1+3
f(-1)=20+3
f(-1)=1+3=4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a function has unknown constants (like a and c), substitute the given (x, y) points into the function to create a system of equations. For exponential terms like <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></msup></math>, remember that <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>2</mn><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>·</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></msup></math>.
